title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation with all stock owned by qualifying individuals, or partnership/trust/estate with all beneficial interests held by qualifying individuals. Qualified Agricultural Property includes single purpose agricultural structures placed in service by the taxpayer over 20 years ago. Qualified Agricultural Property includes single purpose agricultural structures placed in service by the taxpayer more than 20 years before the transfer, as well as related real property, equipment, or fixtures. United States Real Property refers to real property located in the United States. The exchange described in subsection (a) involves transferring structures and related real property, equipment, or fixtures. United States real property refers to real property located in the United States. The taxpayer must identify and complete the exchange within 180 days. The taxpayer must identify exchanged property within 45 days and complete the exchange within 180 days in the United States. The taxpayer must identify exchanged property within 45 days and complete the exchange within 180 days in the United States. If the property to be received is not identified within 45 days or received after 180 days, certain conditions apply. The taxpayer must identify exchanged property within 45 days and complete the exchange within 180 days in the United States. Rules similar to section 1031 apply for basis, exchanges not solely in kind, and related parties. The exchange is treated as a section 1031 exchange for tax purposes. The transfer of relinquished property occurs, with rules similar to section 1031 applying. Transactions described in this section are treated the same as section 1031 exchanges for tax purposes. Additionally, ordinary income recapture is deferred until the disposition of real property acquired in the exchange. The transfer of relinquished property is subject to rules similar to section 1031. Transactions in this section are treated like section 1031 exchanges for tax purposes. Additionally, ordinary income recapture is deferred until the disposition of real property acquired in the exchange. Special rules apply for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property. The code is amended to include a special rule for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property, where the amount of gain recognized by the transferor shall not exceed the sum of the gain recognized on the property. If gain is not recognized under section 1046, the amount of gain taken into account by the transferor shall not exceed the sum of the recognized gain on the disposition and the fair market value of property acquired that is not accounted for. The amount of gain recognized on the disposition, plus the fair market value of property acquired that is not section 1245 property or United States real property, determines the ordinary income recapture on the disposition of real property acquired in an exchange. If United States real property acquired in an exchange is sold, the ordinary income recapture is based on the excess of the amount realized on the sale. When United States real property acquired in an exchange is sold, the recapture is based on the excess of the amount realized on the sale over the adjusted basis of the property. When qualified agricultural property is sold, exchanged, or involuntarily converted, the recapture is based on the excess of the fair market value over the adjusted basis of the property. When qualified agricultural property is disposed of, the recapture is calculated based on the excess of fair market value over the adjusted basis of the property. When qualified agricultural property is disposed of, any gain recognized as ordinary income on the disposition of such property shall be treated as ordinary income, regardless of other provisions in the tax code. The effective date for these amendments is specified in subsection (a). The amendments specify that gain from the disposition of qualified agricultural property will be treated as ordinary income, regardless of other tax provisions. The effective date for these changes varies based on the type of transfer or disposition. SPECIAL RULES FOR INSTALLMENT SALES OF QUALIFIED AGRICULTURAL PROPERTY. Special rule for qualified agricultural property in installment sales under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The sale of qualified agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows income to be accounted for using the installment method, with recognized income from the sale being treated as recapture income in the same proportion for each taxable year. Under the installment method for the sale of qualified agricultural property, income recognized in a taxable year is treated as recapture income in that year in proportion to the total recapture income from the sale. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment of this Act, with changes to the installment method for the sale of qualified agricultural property.
